labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Do we want to differentiate DNS64 vs local synthesis cases?
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
I think it might be useful to test with RFC8781 w/o DNS64 as a primary case and maybe have a separate case (?) for DNS64 presence?
It would be desirable to ensure that there are no dependencies on DNS64?

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
As part of a section on name resolution issues to look for, that makes very much sense.

@furry13 ideas who may want to contribute a section on that?

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: We might want to have a 'network topologies' section

issues.title: CLAT case needs to be mentioned explicitly?
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: When "IPv6-only + NAT64" client is tested, do we want to ensure that the OS doesn't have CLAT enabled, so I guess it's worth mentioning explicitly

comments.author: mstojens
comments.body: I think so. If the terms are split, fine. If not, I suggest renaming this term "IPv6-mostly" rather than mention NAT64 specifically in the term itself (the definition of course is fine).

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
Makes sense to clarify that we want no CLAT for testing as it is covered in Dual-Stack or IPv4 only.

I also thought about mentioning IPv6-mostly initially, but in the end, IPv6-mostly is from a client perspective either dual-stack (464XLAT, no option 108 so native v4) or IPv6-only (with IPv6 or IPv4 behind NAT64). So I focus on NAT64 as everything else is covered in Dual-Stack or IPv4-only.

issues.title: Rename "unlikely" category
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
The current text says:

"The other combinations are unlikely to exhibit additional problems and therefore are marked as unlikely"

IMHO it's. bit optimistic, and might send a wrong message that it needs to be tested.
 I'd rather move them to 'basic' category (or maybe renaming all cstegories)

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body: This is definitely a trade-off. I am happy to rename it to _extended_ and make it sound a little less optional, but having a too large basic set will reduce probability testing is done at all. For our Zoo, I have not seen a single application that had a Problem on in these scenarios. Mayme it makes sense to batch that with STUN/TURN and mention that these cases definitely need checking the extended set.

issues.title: Explicitly mention MTU/fragmentation testing
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: as IPv4/IPv6/NAT64 networks might exhibit different behaviours, it would be nice to mention it

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
Cases:

1. MTU in RA == 1280
2. Router uplink with MTU=1280 and MTU in RA == 1500

issues.title: STUN/TURN cases
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: IF STUN/TURN is involved, it might be needed to test more cases (all combinations with clients + all combinations of servers)

issues.title: Definition: "IPv[46] Connectivity
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
As it was discussed at v6ops during Ondrej presentation, we might want to have a standard definition of "connectivity".

Default gateway? non-link-local IPs?

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
That's a hard one… for this document, I'm quite tempted to explicitly define that as out-of-scope.
It gets really confusing to get that one right if you can have partial IPv6 and Partial IPv4 connectivity over multiple links/VPNs and each resource may or may not be available over random subsets of these either for address family, routing, and policy reason.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
We can say sm th like 'in the vast majority of cases it is sufficient to have a default route". However some apps might require testing more specific routes.

?? Do we want to consider CLAT as 'IPV4 connectivity'?

issues.title: Warn against VPNs like Apple Private Relay
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body: Explain how this can screw IPv6 only testing

issues.title: Add/Mention customer support perspective
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> I think the introduction might want to say more about how this document might
interact with diagnosis of end-customer problems.  With the view to avoiding
the "Just turn off IPv6" that comes from many places, and which might just
result in confused tech-support when there winds up being no connectivity :-)

issues.title: Add considerations for proxies and other application layer mechanisms to Section 4
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
We already have the Apple Private relay stuff in Sec. 4.1, but that needs more generalization & explanation

From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> When you write *proxy*, there are SOCKS and HTTP proxies and other
application layer mechanisms (ultimately: SMTP "bridged" by UUCP[%]...), which
might be reachable over one protocol, and then provide connectivity of a different
kind.   The combinatorics here are large.   In particular, the connectivity
of the proxy itself can go all through all the combinations Table 1!

issues.title: Reference RFC8520 in Section 6.2?
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> Section 6.2 might want to reference MUD, RFC8520.

issues.title: Discuss broken DNS A/AAAA scenarios
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> if prune the A RR is a method, then they
may also need to insert phony/broken AAAA RRs, and then one has to worry
about permutting the order of RR returned.

This can also happen through mis-configured DNS servers, "DNS security appliances” or miscommunication between DNS and LB teams… Maybe add as scenario for Section 5

issues.title: Fix/broaden perspective of test scenarios
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> Maybe there are a few new sections needed for:
> 1. residential IoT
> 2. on-premise services and appliances.
> 2b.  a subset of this would include Enterprise IoT.
> 2c.  I think of routing/switching infrastructure as being the original IoT,
    or, maybe, "Things of Internet"... because how does your XYZ vendor
    routing platform call v4-home to validate licenses or update firmware
    when there is no v4?
> 3. Among the v6-only, but-not-v6-global, would include SNAC.
  Right now, this mechanism is focused on low-speed, challenged STUB
  Networks.   However, one interesting way to deploy a cluster of systems
  (could even be entirely virtual) to an Enterprise would be with a v6-only
  STUB network.
